message_text: Helping your children learn
PLH - Internal - Update incomplete toolkits
@fields.from_theme

COVID-19 has interrupted our children's education with school closures and remote learning. It is normal to feel overwhelmed about to do this alone, especially when we also have stress about work and money.
@parent.results.fromwelcome
@fields.type_of_media
Here's a video to help you support your child's learning.
Here's an audio message to help you support your child's learning.
PLH - Internal - Update toolkits
Would you like to learn more about how to support your children with remote learning and returning to school?

That's okay! You can always type "Help" at anytime if you need any support with your children. Chat to you later!

Here are 5 steps that you can do to help your children continue learning during this time:

1. Create a routine around learning and schoolwork
2. Make learning fun and playful
3. Remember that you are a parent NOT a substitute teacher 
4. Stay connected with your child's school and teachers
5. Support your child when they return to school

Type "1" to "5" to learn more about each tip. Type "N" to stop this tip.
@fields.child_nickname

Step 1. Create a routine around learning and schoolwork

Make a daily plan with @fields.child_nickname for when they can spend time doing educational activities. This can include structured schoolwork and other activities online, reading, writing, or arts. Allow flexibility and time for play and relaxation too.

Step 1. Create a routine around learning and schoolwork

Make a daily plan with your child for when they can spend time doing educational activities. This can include structured schoolwork and other activities online, reading, writing, or arts. Allow flexibility and time for play and relaxation too.
@fields.child_nickname

Step 2. Make learning fun and playful

Children learn best when learning is fun! Try to find ways to make learning playful to keep @fields.child_nickname interested and engaged. Type "Help" if you ever need any fun ideas!

Step 2. Make learning fun and playful

Children learn best when learning is fun! Try to find ways to make learning playful to keep your child interested and engaged. Type "Help" if you ever need any fun ideas!
@fields.child_nickname
@fields.gender_personalisation

Step 3. Remember that you are a father NOT a substitute teacher! 

Your role is to support your child by creating a space to learn. You do not need to know all the answers. Help them explore their interests and ask questions. Go at @fields.child_nickname's pace and be patient with yourself.

Step 3. Remember that you are a mother NOT a substitute teacher! 

Your role is to support your child by creating a space to learn. You do not need to know all the answers. Help them explore their interests and ask questions. Go at @fields.child_nickname's pace and be patient with yourself.

Step 3. Remember that you are a mother NOT a substitute teacher! 

Your role is to support your child by creating a space to learn. You do not need to know all the answers. Help them explore their interests and ask questions. Go at your child's pace and be patient with yourself.

Step 3. Remember that you are a parent NOT a substitute teacher! 

Your role is to support your child by creating a space to learn. You do not need to know all the answers. Help them explore their interests and ask questions. Go at your child's pace and be patient with yourself.
@fields.child_nickname

Step 4. Stay connected with your child's school and teachers

Find out how to stay in touch with @fields.child_nicknameâ€™s teacher or school to stay informed, ask questions and get more guidance. If you are struggling or know someone who is struggling with school work or the home situation, please discuss this with a teacher that you feel close to. Parent groups or community groups can also be a good way to support each other with your home schooling.

Step 4. Stay connected with your child's school and teachers

Find out how to stay in touch with your childrenâ€™s teacher or school to stay informed, ask questions and get more guidance. If you are struggling or know someone who is struggling with school work or the home situation, please discuss this with a teacher that you feel close to. Parent groups or community groups can also be a good way to support each other with your home schooling.
@fields.child_nickname

Step 5. Support your child when they go back to school

Tell @fields.child_nickname that it is okay to feel scared or worried about going back to school. Allow your child to share how they are feeling. It is also normal if your child behaves differently to their usual behaviour. Discuss how going to school might be different and how they can protect themselves from COVID-19. Ask them how their day went and support them if they experienced any difficulties.

Step 5. Support your child when they go back to school

Tell your child that it is okay to feel scared or worried about going back to school. Allow your child to share how they are feeling. It is also normal if your child behaves differently to their usual behaviour. Discuss how going to school might be different and how they can protect themselves from COVID-19. Ask them how their day went and support them if they experienced any difficulties.
